awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Evolutions in Urban Chemistry: Growing Influence of Non-Traditional Emission Sources Workshop; Boulder, Colorado; Fall of 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports a workshop, "Evolutions in Urban Chemistry: Growing Influence of Non-Traditional Emissions Sources" to be held in Boulder, Colorado for two days in the Fall of 2018.  The goal of the workshop is to bring together experts to advance scientific understanding of air pollutant emissions from "non-traditional" man-made sources including cooking, building exhaust, and volatile chemical products (VCPs), such as personal care products. This workshop will bring together experts to develop a roadmap for future research to advance the fundamental understanding of chemical species emitted from these non-traditional sources, how these emissions change chemically over time in the atmosphere, and the effects they have on the urban air pollution mixture.
 
Historically, urban atmospheric chemistry has been driven by emissions from "traditional" anthropogenic volatile organic compounds (VOCs) resulting from transportation and energy production. However, in recent years, as emissions from vehicles have decreased, other sources of VOCs have begun to play a significant role in the urban air pollution mixture. These non-traditional anthropogenic emissions include petroleum based VCPs, cooking emissions, and building exhaust, which often contain functional groups like alcohols, aldehydes, esters, and ketones. In contrast, the traditional anthropogenic VOC emissions are composed of species such as alkanes, alkenes, and aromatics. As a result, a different set of chemical reactions may be important. Workshop discussions will focus on the following areas: 1) laboratory studies of the transformations of oxygenated VOCs from VCPs either in chambers or aqueous solution; 2) field work to characterize emissions and chemical transitions of VCPs in the urban atmosphere; 3) modeling of VCP emissions and their chemical transformations impacting ozone and aerosol concentrations; and 4) development of instrumentation to accurately measure these species and their reaction products at concentrations found in the urban atmosphere. A report synthesizing the discussion will be produced and available broadly.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A two-day workshop was held on 16-17 January 2019 at the University of Colorado Boulder to discuss the evolving, scientific understanding of the role of volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions in urban air pollution. VOCs have important impacts on urban air pollution: some are toxic while others are reactive and contribute to the formation of ozone and haze in urban air. Historically, motor vehicles and industrial sources were the dominant sources of VOCs in urban air, but their emissions have been so effectively curbed that other VOC sources are now relatively more important. These sources include emissions associated with the use of various household, gardening and automotive chemical products, cooking, building materials and many other sources; and these have traditionally not been studied in much detail by the atmospheric chemistry community. The specific VOCs released from these sources are also very different from those released by vehicles and industry: the VOCs from motor vehicles are dominated by hydrocarbons (unburnt fuels), but the VOCs released from these non-traditional sources contain very different chemicals, including functionalized compounds (alcohols, ketones, esters, glycol ethers), fragrances, silicon-containing compounds, and many others. Such VOCs are not commonly measured in urban air, they have not been studied extensively in the laboratory and thus their impacts on urban air pollution are still relatively uncertain.

During the workshop, participants discussed the latest scientific insights regarding these non-traditional VOCs: what are the important sources, by what mechanisms are the VOCs released to the atmosphere, how can they be measured, what do measurements in ambient measurements show, what laboratory work has been done to study the chemistry of these VOCs, and what have we learned about the impacts from air quality models that incorporate these VOCs? Finally, participants discussed high-priority research needs including the development of instruments that can measure these non-traditional VOCs, a better quantification of emissions, an improved understanding of the chemistry that these VOCs can undergo, and the challenges to bring our best understanding of sources, concentrations, and chemistry together in air-quality models.

Intellectual merits of the workshop include a broadening of the scope of atmospheric chemistry studies to non-traditional VOC sources and specific classes of VOCs that are emerging as the dominant organic pollutants in urban air. Also, the workshop brought together ambient air pollution scientists with those studying indoor environments, where a large fraction of these non-traditional VOCs is released. This collaboration between two scientific communities is essential to make progress on this topic.

Broader impacts of the workshop include the potential to improve air quality models and forecasts. A better understanding of urban air pollution is needed to implement effective policies and limit the adverse effects on humans, vegetation, and visibility. Pollutants such as ozone and fine particles have been effectively reduced by clean air policies, but recent trends have shown a slowing in the rate of decrease. The underlying reasons need to be understood to design (cost-) effective policies for the future. Finally, the workshop contributed to the training of two graduate students, who participated fully in the workshop and experienced how new scientific insights shape the direction of research.
